title: Far outweighs other flash card apps
comment: Some great features: (1) whiteboard - allows you to practice writing Chinese characters on the screen (2) night mode - practice on a black background for when you are on your bed at night studying (3) no field limitation - eg have a card make you produce the word from a picture, audio, language 1, language 2, etc (4) you determine spaced repetition - review card in 1 min, 10 min, 4 days are the default button options, (5) suspend button - never see again the cards you already know, but not deleting them
Excellent tool. I really love that.

title: Top Notch SRS in your pocket
comment: Disregard the comment about not supporting audio and images, it does and more. This is Pro level software. The whole Anki system takes work to learn. Read the Anki manual to understand how to properly make and use decks/notes/cards/tags/filtered decks. There are loads of articles and forum posts about tweaks and best practices, I'd suggest reading the manual first. The software and system are a long term investment that if used properly will become a lifelong companion in memorization.

title: Literally life changing

The ease of recall provided by spaced repetition is simply like nothing else I've known, and Anki + Anki Droid is the best platform I've ever tried for it (vs mnemosyne, headmagnet, and supermemo - haven't tried any others). This app is what got me into med school. I can recite reams of poetry as easily as breathing, thanks to Anki. By God, I can even name all fifty states now!

title: Mute audio?
comment: Thanks for the (very) prompt reply before! Is there a way to mute audio in this app (during reviews) while playing music in another?

Hi Dammy, this is not currently possible, but I added a new issue on the tracker:
https://code.google.com/p/ankidroid/issues/detail?id=2643

When I first used Anki, my different devices would not sync up with each other even though they were listed as supported devices. But now my devices happily sync up my custom and shared decks, so I have no complaints- it's fast, convenient, makes learning make sense, and gives you more types of feedback on your studying than any other program. I love it. The online version has a prettier interface than mobile and PC, but I still love the system.

Hi Kathleen, what exactly do you mean by "it doesn't work"? If you can't find your solution in the manual (https://ankidroid.org/docs/manual.html#AnkiDesktop) then please post to the support forum for assistance: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/anki-android

title: Unique: ALL of the numerous functions offline available, Sync possibility, no bugs, active open source development

Unique characteristics: • ONLY Flashcards App that has ALL functions also OFFLINE, • SYNC possibility over Ankiweb for multiple devices, • many functions, • almost no bugs, • good and active open-source development (bug fixes every week, AFAIK), • more complicated tasks done with Anki desktop, • still potential for improvement regarding more functions.

It brings the full power of SRS to mobile devices, so I can study anywhere, all for free. I'm truly thankful for the team that created and updates it voluntarily - you guys rock!

title: Essential for learning a language
comment: Things I love about Anki:  Fully customizable cards. Easily create reverse cards with one entry. Organize with tags Sync across multiple platforms Share and import decks for free  Additionally, Anki's algorithm for determining how often to show you cards is fantastic.  I made a ton of notecards once to help me study Persian and I never used them because they were so clunky to carry around.  Anki makes it easy to put in time each day.

title: Problems solved!
comment: Thanks a lot to developers for helping me out of a problem pestering me. Actually, the leech threshold was set to 1 and thus it did not allow me to study further. Now, it's all good. Thanks again for such a wonderful app.  **Also for those who wanted to italisize-- use < i > Panthera < /i >. It will appear italisized in the preview. In place of i you can use b to make bold, u to underline and so on.

title: Best Flashcard App on the market
comment: There is no doubt that this app is the best flashcard app on the market. It is extremely flexible and offers countless ways to customize your deck. I personally prefer to create the cards on my desktop and sync with my portable devices. Include pictures and sound with your cards, enable the whiteboard to write your answers, require that the answer be typed in, create cloze cards etc. You can even create multiple cards with one click: forwards/backwards/spelling or use it to have one image with several labeled parts, each part with its own card. If you don't want all of this, you can also just keep your cards simple. I highly recommend watching a tutorial video or reading the manual so that you can make the most of this amazing app.
I love it!
Excellent!

title: Use it every day for everything
comment: From the Kings of England to  the poems of Yeats, JavaScript functions and Japanese kanji, I'm a walking dictionary thanks to Anki. It syncs to all devices, can be accessed through the browser or dedicated apps, and resets every day for a new session, focusing only on the cards that gave me trouble. I use it for presentations too: a card and a story for every PowerPoint slide. The front has the picture on the slide; the back has the point to be made. Using Anki prior to presenting makes nervousness vanish.

title: Used for ages, and amazing - some ideas below
comment: I've had this for ages. I originally hated it, but I later gave it a chance, and it has grown on me. I love it now. Feature #1: Can you make it so spacing affects position? The app ignores multiple spaces.  Experimental feature #1: Can you make a feature to edit pieces of text in cards, like being able to make word(s) bold, different colours etc. (not all different shades though) I say experimental, so someone has the ability to turn it on/off, in case it makes it laggy.  Experimental feature #2: Can you make it possible to input superscript and subscript numbers and signs (mainly for chemical equations - no android keyboards seem to have them) so like 1, 2, +, - (g) etc. Sorry that it's a massive wall of text. P.S. I can only use Ankidroid on my ASUS tablet, as I have no computer of my own.  Experimental feature # 3: Can you integrate a drawing app? As in make it so I can draw in my notes and save it.  A lot to ask, but these are mainly just things I would like. It's already definitely worth the 5 stars.

title: Used to replace VCE
comment: Things to love,  gradually introduces new flash cards.  Free desktop application, free android application. Cross platform application. Cons:  importing can be tricky.  Below might help. IPhone app is a paid app  Took a little work but here is how you import a PDF test file.  Use exam collection "exam formatter 3"   Anki Formating  1. Format PDF with exam formatter3,  export format Q.  2. Use Word to Replace command “Paragraph mark”  with Html 'page break '3. Use Word to Replace command “Q.” with “Paragraph mark”Q.  4. Use Word to Replace command “Answer:” with “tab” Answer:  5. save as a Utf-8 txt file  6. Import in Anki

title: Great - needs progressive answer reveal
comment: Helps in memorizing facts.  please add progressive revelation of answer. For example, the first anatomy picture above had 3 facts on 3 separate lines.  instead of just one 'Show Answer' button, have two buttons - 'Show next line' and 'Show all answer' or words to similar effect.  This could be an option in settings for just having one button or the progressive two buttons.  This would help in memorizing long answers - eg long verses, a longer lists than the above etc. I used lots of line breaks to make only the first line of the answer show.  Scrolling line per line as  I  recite allows me to check for perfect recall per line before continuing.  However with Anki updates, Anki now forces the display of most or all of the answer on hitting 'Show Answer'.  All the cards have to be changed again to control the flow of answer being revealed.  Too much at once and its difficult to check if  I recited perfectly or not. It's just like an anatomy picture with 20 items.  Answer 1, check, anwer 2 check -etc The hint would take lots of time to make each card.  Show one line at a  time would make cards easier to produce = more study time.

Hello David, you can achieve the same effect by using Hint Fields. You can create Hint Fields using Anki Desktop:
http://ankisrs.net/docs/manual.html#hint-fields

Edit: You don't need to type the code for the hint on each card, you just add it once to the card template. Please post in the forum for more help if you can't figure out how to do this.

title: What I was looking for
comment: In the 90s, hoping to study Sanskrit vocabulary more efficiently, I looked around for flexible, ergonomic, free flashcard software and finally resorted to writing my own. Today I am happy to report that AnkiDroid does exactly what I wanted. Adding cards is easy; the review interface is streamlined and practical to use with one thumb; and it does a good job of showing the cards I am struggling with. Synchronization between AnkiDroid (on a phone and a tablet), the desktop app, and the web site all works smoothly.  The navigation in the AnkiDroid UI confused me somewhat when I first starting using it. For example, the back button moves up to a higher level in the app structure, rather than returning you to the previous screen, which is fine but unexpected. Once I got used to the layout it works well.

title: Update issue
comment: I previously had kanji meanings appear in the answer automatically based on kanji that appeared in my question card. These have now disappeared - I'm not sure if this functionality was thanks to aedict or anki alone, but very saddened to see it go. Any suggestions on re-enabling this?

Hello Duncan, we ended up removing this feature as we are trying to simplify the app and reduce maintenance burden by removing all non-core functionality. We hope to add it back later as an optional plugin, but when that happens depends on how much our volunteer developers contribute towards implementing the plugin framework.

Not evident how to download ready made decks of cards. Overall design a bit confusing. Also, the size of letters can be too small for study thai, for instance.

I like the idea of the app, but there are so many issues. If you get it right twice you have to wait a day to review the word again. So I tried saying I got all them wrong so I could review then whenever I wanted. After you get more than one wrong it will just constantly go back to the words you got wrong; preventing you from practicing other. It also goes in the order that they were added. So as I'm reviewing them more and more, because of memory I can see one word and know what the next word will be.

Hello Tanner,
AnkiDroid is designed to show you cards at the right time, just before you forget them. Why? Because that boosts memorization in the most efficient way. If you want to review earlier, just use the "Custom Study", it will let you "cram card" as often as you want :-)
Thanks for using AnkiDroid!
The AnkiDroid volunteers.

title: Love and hate
comment: I really really enjoy this app, yet the synchronisation feature is so frustrating I couldn't bring myself to give it a full 5 star review. To elaborate, I started off with only ankidroid and was instantly won over by its usefulness. I then decided to make my own deck on the pc version. This is where the program breaks down there is no way to simply add a deck from anki pc to ankidroid without completely overwriting all progress and cards on ankidroid. This is disappointing to say the least.

Hello Bryan, thanks for your feedback! If you sync properly before adding the deck then it will work fine. (also see FAQ: https://code.google.com/p/ankidroid/wiki/FAQ#How_do_I_make_changes_to_my_collection_with_Anki_Desktop?). If it's too late for this, you can export the deck in Anki Desktop, copy it to your device, and then import into AnkiDroid.

title: Initial struggle worthwhile
comment: Working good, finally. I am getting the occasional crash but a sensible backup strategy makes this easy to bear. I don't like the sync function though as it's very slow here in China, especially if you are trying to sync your entire media collection. I explored different ways to sync over USB, most of them causing AnkiDroid to crash for no apparent reason. At the time of this review Google have decided (very stupidly) to remove the USB Mass Storage file transfer protocol in favour of MTP, which is huge pile of odorous excrement. My plan was to use BeyondCompare (a folder comparison tool for Windows) to sync my Anki media. This is not possible with MTP, which forces you to use Anki's built-in sync function. Then I tried several USB Mass Storage enabling apps, some of which worked but AnkiDroid was crashing all the time. All the problems seemed to go away after I installed the latest version of BusyBox and and app called SG USB Mass Storage Enabler. Now I am able to manage my collection from my PC and I am very happy with the results. I hope Google consider re-adding USB Mass Storage mode though. MTP is retarded.
Please add a menu icon for the galaxy S5 and this will be a great app!

title: Good, flexible smart flashcards app
comment: Features that make AnkiDroid stand out from other smart flashcard programs are 1) being able to download and share already-made decks, 2) synchronization between the mobile app, web account, and desktop program for ease of input and use (fuller keyboard on the desktop helps cardmaking), and 3) all of this is free!  My only request is to add abilities to make cards with picture and sound files, e.g. for Art History and Ear Training.

title: Poor, disappointing
comment: 1. Settings with Esoteric Jargon have no explanation, self-explanatory settings have an explanation.  Seems ironic. (-2 stars) 2. Can't modify interval times (-4 stars) 3.important features like repeat sound have been removed. Being able to repeat the sound repeatedly after having seen the definition is essential for me  (-5 stars).  Add that to the tally of 3 stars for a so-so srs with a clunky interface and no tutorial, in-app docs, and empty wik, you get -8 stars. Need people who actually understand learning to be on the development team.

Hi Andrew,
We need YOU on the development team :-)
For the next release we actually slashed many options, in order to make settings clearer.
Your feedback is very welcome for the user interface, please send all feedback to anki-android@googlegroups.com
We're happy to discuss the other points as well.
Cheers!
The AnkiDroid volunteers.

title: Officially DONE
comment: I'm DONE with this program.  For one, it doesn't allow cramming.  When you finish a deck, you have FINISHED that deck for the day.  I couldn't figure out how to reset it to let me study the words again.  Which brings me to two, the program is unnecessary complicated.  I used sticky kanji to study for the JLPT and while I couldn't make my own flashcards, I didn't need to read anything to start using it.  It just worked.  Finally, the last straw.  I go to make a deck for my final exam and it tells me my entries are in other decks.  I can't have duplicates.  It's okay, Anki, I want doubles, this is my compilation deck.  No? YOU WON'T ALLOW ME?  What kind of programmer make s program that won't let me use it?  I am not going to search for and move my old cards.  Oh and that option to try to keep pairs apart from one another?  Doesn't work very well at all.  I'm just really annoyed right now.

title: A highly versatile study tool
comment: Anki is an very flexible tool that can be used to study many subjects in many ways. There is large ecosystem of community decks and plug-ins for the desktop version. The plug-ins can be useful across platforms. For example, I use the tts plug-in to generate audio clips for my Chinese vocab cards which are then available in the android app after a sync.  Cards are highly customizable,  they use html templates and can contain images and audio.

title: Very useful. Great learning tool
comment: I used this to make cards for my language class and it worked really well. It not only allows you to make flashcards, but also manages your learning -- giving you daily "assignments" and organizing the cards you know well, the ones you know a bit, and the ones you don't know at all so that you get more repetition of things that are hard to acquire. I'm a teacher and find that this app uses the principles of learning very well.  Synching with my computer is a little confusing though.

title: One of the most annoying Apps I use
comment: A flashcard app seems like it should be the type of thing so intuitive that students studying software development constantly build their own for their end of term projects. This type of software requires only a basic grasp of database usage and a simple user interface. So HOW IN THE HELL does ANKI make it SO F^$%# IMPOSSIBLE to do something as SIMPLE as REVERSE A DECK OF CARDS?!?!?! Flashcards 101: 99.9% of people who use apps like this will at some point need to study their cards forwards and backwards. There should be a 1-button click option to do so. Meanwhile, In ANKI-Land, Ive spent the last hour trying to follow through their ridiculously unnecessary steps to perform this simple task. Im still trying to figure it out as I write this.

title: Best flashcard app.
comment: Excellent application of scientific principles of learning.

I use it for learning Chinese. I love how easy it is to make your own cards and that the app automatically learns which things you need to review more often and which you don't because you know them well.

A little bit of a learning curve, but most definitely worth the effort!	Tried AnkiDroid, found it too complicated, then tried the other free alternatives. The alternatives all had terrible interfaces and lacked a decent method on data entry via a computer (either via the web or a standalone desktop application) so I went back to AnkiDroid.  It took me a little while to get used to the PC and Android apps, but once I did... Ohhh man the program really shines. The "spaced repetition" technique has really helped with my studies, and the interface is far more pleasant and clean than all the others.  Definitely impressed with this free and fully featured flash cards app. Works perfectly on my Nexus 10 and Galaxy S2.
AMAZINGGGG

title: Can't export decks from the mobile app, very disappointed.

If you only plan on using it on your Android phone (and only need simple text cards), it's fantastic.  However, I recently received an iPhone and wanted to transfer my decks.  There is an iPhone version, but it costs $25 (understandably, it goes toward supporting development of all versions of the app); if you can't afford it at the moment (like me) there's always the simple mobile web version.  But all of my decks were created on my Android and can't be exported.  So I have to recreate my 100+ cards one at a time. ):

title: I learned 1,000 definitions in 10 days.. seriously
comment: I'm in med school. The neuroscience block is a ~6 week period where students are pushed to the limit regarding memorization skills. Students are expected to learn well over 1,000 definitions over a 6 week period. I didn't truly realize this hefty requirement until roughly 10 days before the exam, as I was busy with practice questions and conceptual learning (usually the best way to study but NOT for the neuroscience block). I frantically searched for a worthy flashcard app. I had one I was happy with but it just couldn't handle the magnitude of flashcards I needed to make.  Long story short, I learned over 1,000 definitions in 10 days with Anki... I should have failed... badly. I made a strong B instead.  1)Free on Google Play ($30 on iTunes) 2)Free desktop app with sync between devices and Mac/PC 3)More options/settings than I will ever need 4)Neuroscience Fact: Your brain has the capacity to store more information than you could memorize in 100 lifetimes (and much more) so download Anki, learn how to use it (~15min) and quickly master any type of information you want. 4a)This is NOT just perfect for language, Anki's learning algorithm is perfect for memorizing. Period.
Very heavy user of this excellent app

comment: I really like this app.  The algorithm for displaying cards is effective.  The ability to customize cards, etc. puts this app ahead of other flashcard apps, imho.  However, there is one major drawback.  Currently there is no "swap" feature.  In other words, the same side of the card will always be displayed.  In flashcard learning being able to start with the opposite side is crucial.  There is a method for swapping individual cards, but if you have a large set (e.g. - 1,000 Spanish words), individually swapping each card is not tenable.  If this feature is added, I would rate this 5 stars.

title: Wonderful, But Ugly Widget
comment: I've used Anki on the PC for studying languages for years, and the Android app is incredible.  I make cards on my PC in a txt file, import them into Anki PC, and they automatically sync.  Easy, and it's far easier to be diligent about studying when you're away from a computer.  Yes, the interface is slightly annoying, but the trade-off is extreme depth: sort cards by tags (want to study just verbs from your language deck? No problem), see progress/forecast charts, edit, etc.  There are two different settings menus (one for Anki, one for decks) and I always flip between them trying to find my setting.  Simply being able to make the cards easily on a PC is enough to make Anki is killer.  No ads, either.  This program is simply the best flash card program you can work.  Seriously, though, its widget is the worst.  I love seeing my card count for the day, but it's somewhat larger than an icon, and just looks ugly anywhere I put it.  Something a bit more standard would be wonderful.

title: An impressive open source implementation of Anki
comment: As a former AnkiMobile user I was a bit cautious to switch to Android because I was not sure how well AnkiDroid would work. AnkiMobile is a paid app and thus support was expected. In case something went wrong with my decks I could always get it fixed by the developer.  But it turns out that my fears were ungrounded with AnkiDroid. AnkiDroid has worked flawlessly in the past two months I have used it. Though I have purposefully tried not do anything complicated like adding media or even cards. I have mainly used it for reviewing and always closed the collection by exiting the app with the back button. If used simply for reviewing, filtering, searching and editing there should be no problems at all. I would say that AnkiDroid is on par with AnkiMobile. Maybe even better in some respects :D  In short I am very impressed with AnkiDroid. Thank you to all the developers and contributors who spend their time improving it. Also a huge thanks to Damien Elmes. Anki is the number one reason anyone should get a smart phone.

Teen sanastot kuvineen ja puheineen tietokoneella, josta synkronoin ne verkkosivustolle ja puhelimeeni. Puhelimestani opettelen sanat kirjotettuina ja puhuttuina päivittäin työmatkallani. Jos omien sanastojen tekoon jaksaa laittaa hieman vaivaa, niin tämä on erinomainen työkalu monenlaiseen opiskeluun. Myös valtava määrä valmiita kortistoja ladattavissa AnkiWebistä.

title: 5 stars for Anki1, 0 for Anki2
comment: I really love the first version of Anki and I've been using it nonstop to teach myself swahili by using pictures, sound files and just direct word to word translations, and my daughter has been using it to study for her anatomy tests.  I whip out my phone in long grocery store lines and study a quick 10 cards here or there. I love the functionality, the ease of use and the tracking system.  I made the mistake of downloading Anki 2 because they disabled the deck sharing for the original version.  I should have left well enough alone!  Anki 2 is like a house in the process of being built: it's got a foundation and some exposed studs and beams, but no working bathroom, kitchen or electricity.  Essentially it's a shell of its former self. Unusable.   Well, says I, I'll just revert back to Anki 1 and wait until they have a full working version. So I reverted (all my painstakingly constructed decks are backed up) but it will no longer let me add cards, make revisions or sync. It no longer recognizes my log in creds. Continuing the house analogy, it's like I came back to my old home to find the locks changed. Very sad, Anki. Very sad.

It's "algorithm" based learning theory doesn't work well for large quantities of data.  Like a language deck of 5,000 cards.  Because wrong answers come back up randomly, versus assessing and reviewing all wrong answers together, and retesting them together as an option.  If you need to do an assessment exam, that simulates the real quiz, Anki isn't the best.

title: Requesting Dropbox support
comment: This is a great port of the original Anki program. It even has some additional features the original doesn't have (night mode, some additional statistics like how many days left to complete the deck). So far, so good in terms of basic functionality. However, I'm really hoping they will add Dropbox support. Rather than using the web Anki, I'd prefer to use my Dropbox, which also includes media files the Anki Web doesn't have. As a result, my Android decks are lacking media like images that are on my computer's version.

title: Great, but for a few things

title: Memorization couldn't be easier
comment: Anki, and the Android app in particular, enabled me to get almost perfect scores on glossary and kanji tests in Japanese class with minimal effort. Some 15 minutes a day is all you need - perfect if you commute by train or bus.

User UI is counter intuitive. Back button close the app when I expect it would show the list of all the deck I have.	Pressing the top deck name should do the same. And not an settings icon. It's confusing.  Anyway I found the navigation very hard to master. Even a simple task as finding decks. Simpler, homogenous, intuitive UI is needed.

title: Hunh?  Why such a high rating?
comment: I don't get it.  The droid interface is not bad, but the desktop application and AnkiWeb are extremely cumbersome.  Looking for a flashcard reader I can share among platforms and users was a HUGE time waster!  The AnkiWeb is awful, how do you change deck names?  The desktop app is awful, I want to import and it has to be in UTF-8 from a CSV.  Why?  And, then I exported and the darn export file is LOCKED?  What's up w/ that?  Also, the cards available from the 'community' for I wanted was limited to none!  I found more on anymemo or another one.  But, I don't like those either, I digress.  I would say that I do like the interface and the algorithm that Ankidroid uses on my droid phone.  there was one other flashcard program where you could only go through the cards sequentially and you had to slide them.  I'll get carpal tunnel from all the sliding, so Anki is better there.    In all, I don't get the 4.5 average stars, maybe 2.  the time invested and lack of intuitive feel is excruciating.  Steve Jobs would fire you...

title: The update makes this SUPERB!
comment: I have really hopped around a lot when it comes to flash cards. We bought the full Mental Case for iphones and our macs. But then I decided to try mnemosyne. Then I hopped to anki, then back to mental case then back to Anki now. With the new updates to the Android app, Anki is the best flash card option for me on my android ICS tablet. Love it! Love that it estimates how long it will take me to do my reviews for the day. Love that it keeps track of how well I know a topic. This is an Excellent resource that more and more of my medical student colleagues are starting to use for exam review!     Suggestion: Would be brilliant if Anki allowed attaching images to the app, if that is possible.

title: Hands down best for kanji flashcards
comment: I've been using Anki for over two years now and have become progressively more impressed with it as it's matured.  Only problem I ever had with FCs ended up being a problem with my SD card being corrupted, and I've used it on Froyo, Gingerbread, and ICS devices.  It's currently running flawlessly on my Galaxy Nexus.  I love the fact that there are so many options for customizing cards/reviews, although  finding all the relevant features can be overwhelming after a major upgrade since things are sometimes relocated to totally new locations in the interface.  One gripe is that syncing is manual.  I'd really appreciate an auto-sync feature that would update the cloud copy on completing a session or exiting the app.  But what's really great is the Japanese plugin in the associated desktop application that autogenerates the furigana readings for kanji flashcards.  It makes creation of japanese vocabulary cards extremely fast and simple on a WinPC.  ...in fact, that's my only remaining criticism of AnkiDroid...being that I've started using an Android tab as a laptop replacement, I'd really love seeing a similar feature available for the card creator in AnkiDroid.

title: Needs an update for ICS
comment: I had this when I had gingerbread and loved it. Never had a single problem. One of the main reasons I chose another android was for this program but the ICS version is REALLY buggy.   -It crashes daily.   -For whatever reason, about 75% of the time the settings button does not show up when I'm doing reviews so I can't edit cards as I go.   -Unlike the GB version, this one did not prompt me to choose "sync from local" and I lost 100 flashcards during a sync.   -Backups don't work right and I can't find a way to actually restore from backup. I had to make a whole new deck and load it from my computer, sync from computer, then sync the new deck onto my droid...  -I'm getting some kind of database error now from the ankidroid PC program.  -When browsing card lists, the sort option does not work (when sorting by date)  Despite all this I would say it's still the best flashcard program out there. If you're not on ICS I highly recommend it. If you ARE on ICS then I still recommend it but be careful and expect to get a little frustrated but the good is worth the bad.  When I get an update that fixes some of these problems I will edit my review back up to a 5.

title: Great for learning anything you can put on cards
comment: I've been using Anki & Ankidroid for over a year, mostly for the Russian Language as a companion to my night classes. It's great to make a custom deck on the computer with free Anki software, then practice/review wherever and whenever on my phone. It works best if you make your own deck. The quality of the free shared decks is spotty, and they're not super easy to browse, but there are some good ones. If you're serious about learning a subject you'd probably want to make your own decks anyway.  I'm knocking it to 4 stars because the sync service could handle multiple device sync collisions better, but the new version does auto backups, so I think it's better than it used to be. Just sync often if you use Anki/Ankidroid on multiple devices.
